bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, January 16, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] asks Connor for a translation of a text on the pre-Columbian Yucatan. He believes yellow fever may have existed among the Maya.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, January 16, 1922

opener.dateline:
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
January 16, 1922.

div1.p:
Dr. Russell (I. H. B.) was here yesterday and tells me that you
have an article in some magazine on yellow fever among the Mayas. If
so, please tell me when and where it was published so that I can get
it.

Mr. Spinden, of whom you wrote me in the spring, has an article
in the December World's Work: In my judgment unconvincing. Too long
to criticise, but it seems enough to say that he locates many of his
epidemics in the City of Mexico: An error of this kind throws doubt
on the remainder and there are other slips.

I am enclosing in this an excerpt from Finlay's quotation from
Bishop Ancona's translations from the Chumayel MSS. and Tizimin Codex--
which I sent you before.

If convenient could you have some competent person verify or
correct the translations submitted: (a) as to their existence in the
original and (b) as to the accuracy of the translation.

If the phrases underscored are correctly transcribed and trans-
lated and which is really meant for an illness--“blood-vomit,”--I would
count the pre-Columbian existence of yellow fever in Yucatan as proven.
Possibly xekik may be the name of another god--like “Kuk” or “Kan-
tenal!” The fact of the word meaning “blood-vomit” is not absolutely
negative: Among the Hill Tribes of India “Mata” is the name of a god-
dess and also of small-pox, of which she has become the titular patron-
ess.
